Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Competing Demands and Future Vulnerability of Groundwater: Drinking Water Quality and Food Security in Arsenic-Impacted South and Southeast Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hundreds of millions of people worldwide are exposed to dangerous arsenic (As) levels by drinking untreated groundwater. As contamination causes a variety of severe health problems in humans, including several forms of cancer and increased infant mortality Recent field evidence shows how human activities can elevate As concentrations and suggests many more people could be affected in the coming decades. Massive groundwater pumping for the supply of both megacities and rice irrigation could contaminate deep aquifers that currently have low levels of As, by drawing in groundwater that is high in As. Furthermore, irrigation with high-As groundwater markedly reduces the yield of rice crops, threatening food security. The extent of groundwater contamination in affected areas is determined by a combination of individual farmers' practices and the decisions made by large municipalities. In order to study these interactions, the researchers will model how human decisions affect As levels in aquifers across three river basins that have experienced differing degrees of development. The study will identify effective measures to reduce the amounts of As in groundwater and rice crops, leading to safer food and water supplies.

Aquifer vulnerability will be assessed by tracking the penetration of the radioisotopes of hydrogen in water and carbon released to the atmosphere between 1950 and 1970 relative to As in groundwater. Several hundred wells distributed along three 30 km transects, some affected by municipal and irrigation pumping and others not, will be sampled for these and additional tracers. These measurements will be combined with modeling of groundwater flow and As transport to determine whether irrigation pumping or municipal pumping poses a more serious threat. Farmer behavior will be assessed through a randomized controlled trial by providing field-kits for measuring As in irrigation water and paddy soil in some villages and not in others. Currently all rice farmers in the study area use some fertilizer to boost yields, but almost no farmer removes the most contaminated topsoil to reduce As before adding fertilizer and increase yields for years to come. The researchers will examine the tradeoff between a short-term gain and a long-term gain where the one-time investment cost is paired with varying patterns of future benefits. The observations are expected to establish that soil removal and lowering of As in irrigation water will increase rice yields and protect deep low-As groundwater for drinking. More broadly, the research is expected to provide evidence for policy makers that scaling up the adoption of simple alternative approaches can protect groundwater aquifers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project was to protect deep aquifers of the South and Southwast Asia that are low in arsenic from becoming contaminated. Research proceeded on two fronts: (1) sampling of deep aquifers for arsenic and tracers in potentially vulnerable areas and modeling these observations, (2) reducing incentives for farmers to switch to deep pumping for irrigation by reversing losses in rice yield due to the accumulation of arsenic in rice paddies from irrigating with shallow groundwater.

With respect to intellectual merit, this research has shed new light on the hydrogeological processes that determine groundwater circulation and residence time, as well as the interplay with biogeochemical processes that regulate the quality of groundwater. The specific objective the groundwater sampling and analysis was to determine (1) if deep arsenic in the SW Bengal Basin was of natural origin or due to draw-down of elevated arsenic from shallower aquifers, (2) if deeper arsenic 20 km East of Dhaka was related to distal deep municipal pumping. An efficient screening procedure was designed to select problematic wells and state-of-the-art dating techniques by radiocarbon and tritium were applied. Results show that high levels of arsenic in deep aquifers in the border area with India, in the SW Bengal Basin, were most likely of natural origin. In contrast, the high levels of arsenic, increasing over time, within the cone of depression of the capital Dhaka, were attributed to massive municipal pumping.     

In terms of intellectual merit, the agricultural interventions that were conducted over 5 years were original in their design and shed new light on soil-plant interactions that regulate of rice, a major global crop. The field experiments quantified the loss in rice yield attributable to the build-up of arsenic in paddy soil from irrigation with groundwater elevated in arsenic, (2) found ways to mitigate the problem by substitution high-arsenic soil with low-arsenic soil, (3) helped rice farmers determine with a simple kit which if any portions of their field were high in arsenic. The conclusions from this aspect of the research are that (1) winter rice production in Bangladesh is about 5% lower than it would be without arsenic accumulation and this will worsen over time, (2) paddy soil can be inverted to place deeper low-arsenic soil at the top and at least temporarily restore yields provided additional nutrients are provided, (3) a simple field kit manufactured for testing water for arsenic can be used to test arsenic in paddy soil as well.   

In terms of broader impact, three PhD students at Columbia U, MIT, and U Delaware, respectively, were provided with substantial support to complete their thesis through this grant. Overall the project contributed a total of 13 peer-reviewed publications, 7 of which based on field work supported principally by this grant. Locally, the issue of deep aquifer vulnerability has been conveyed to officials of the Bangladesh government's Department of Public Health Engineering. They are aware but see no immediate prospects for ending deep Dhaka pumping, which is likely to continue to reduce access to safe groundwater within the cone depression. In the case of the SW Bengal Basin, we have pointed out that shallow aquifers, which are often low in arsenic in the study area, can be exploited instead of pumping from deep aquifers that are naturally low in arsenic because of accelerated flow paths attributed to a paucity of fine-grained clay and silt in the area.   

We also held meetings with farmers in Bangladesh to discuss the problem of arsenic accumulation in relation to rice yield and explored solutions with them. Some of standard to conduct soil inversion of our design out of their own volition. We have pointed out that this is temporary solution however and that switching to other crops that don't require as much water and aren't as sensitive to arsenic should be considered. Without grant support, soil testing services using the field kit can no longer provided. The amount farmers are willing to pay for such tests turns out not to be sufficient to sustain a commercial service, at least for now.
